data.text: How to Charge My e-Bike when Long-Distance Cycling?

Has anyone ever thought, where do I find power for my e-bike trek?? on the way, sometimes you have to be very inventive to get the necessary watt for your batteries . Someone with hints the more free the better, low budget, low profiles . I was thinking about washers, they must have a socket contact there, right? and most of them are open until 10 pm .
Outdoor soda machines usually have one plug open. üíØ
data.author: Joshua Van Schoik

data.text: to give you an idea in Begie I have to sail a generator to charge 2 batteries, a little stupid right??
data.author: Peter van Huffel

data.text: I know my reply will not be popular among the eriders but by your post your mainly a FREELOADER! Free the better, low budget, low profile? Those were your words. If your gonna ride a bike that requires a battery maybe YOU should provide the means to charge like purchasing a 2nd battery. So by your post you'd pull up to a laundrymat and plug into an outlet (free of charge) and use the owners power without contributing 10 cent to the operation? I guess you wouldn't mind a stranger plugging into an outdoor recpitical at your house. Right? If a trailhead or locale offers charging, if a resturaunt (where your eating) doesn't mind, any scenario like that is ok with using their power then fine. Otherwise, furnish your own power and don't sponge off of others especially nefariously.ike I said, I know my post won't be popular but I'm ok with that. BTW , not an ebike hater. But I do dislike those who always want something for free to fund their good times. Just as I dislike go fund me bums.
data.author: Rick Hancock

data.text: spot on.
data.author: John Axson

data.text: Charles you missed the whole point of my reply. The guy fully stated he was looking for free/ underhanded methods of charging. Doesn't matter if it's a nickle or $5 worth of power. If your obtaining it without permission it's wrong. I don't drink coffee nor do I fly so despite your knowledgeable supposing NO, I DON'T USE EITHER. Yes, I've charged my phone at a resturaunt during a meal and always asked if it was ok. But generally speaking I carry 1-2 power banks in my panniers so I'm self sufficient. It's ridiculous that you can surmise that I'm a snob. Try reading and understanding the comment before opening your big mouth.

data.text: Actually I'm a lot of fun. Been leading backpacking/bikepacking trips for years ( including some eriders). I make it clear that if your on an ebike you need to provide your own means of replenishing power or stay in a campground with electric outlet WHICH YOU PAY FOR!

data.text: slow down a bit‚Ä¶. To fill an empty ebike battery will consume probably a nickel worth of electricity. The owner of the laundromat knows someone may come in and use electricity‚Ä¶ But they also know that the longer they are there the more likely they will use vending machines to buy snacks and the like. Starbucks offers free electricity to charge batteries for this very reason‚Ä¶‚Ä¶
data.author: David O'Neill

data.text: David, that's fine. No complaint. The author of the post stated "free the better, low budget, low profile. As in sneaking around under cover of dark. Etc.
data.author: Rick Hancock

data.text: To the admins who removed my messages/replies. I said nothing out of place. The author of the original pkst was on here several days ago with a pic of a heavily loaded and I mean a curcus load of gear. Several people commented and he took some offense. Which is fine. Today he oosted about acquiring free power for an ebike during a trip. HIS wording indicated means of obtaining without asking. "Free the better, low budget, LOW PROFILE. Which indicates using a power source without permission. An example was a laundromat. He doesn't mention using the phacilities just their outlets. I don't care for freeloaders. And suggested bringing a spare battery or asking for permission. I didn't reize toll later it was the same guy from ladt week. Regardless, people didn't like my reply which was not offensive, rude, nor nasty. It simply pointed out that what he was asking was not fair to a business owner. Taking a nickle or $50 worth of free electricity without asking is or should be illegal. Other people tried to justify the actions and find fault with my post. A post that was fair and follwed the rules. If I'm on a bike trip and want to charge my phone at a resturaunt I ask. If I'm doing laundary and charge my phone that's fair. Doing otherwise is wrong no matter how you justify it.
data.author: Rick Hancock

data.text: I agree with all but the go fund me bums. They are not when they ask for donations to a cause whatever that cause may be. The asked, the other person you describe is taking without asking.
data.author: Donald Ewen

data.text: At the airport or coffee shop the owners expect their outlets to be used that way. Also, those are locations where you are already paying to be at. Personally, I always buy at least a soda if I have to stop and use the restroom at a gas station or fast food joint. Yes, they are theoretically "free" but it seems to be a fair trade.
data.author: David Hothem

data.text: You‚Äôre comparing two completely unrelated things. For starters, cell phone batteries draw a % of the power e bike batteries do. Lastly, you‚Äôre paying for services at an airport or coffee shop. If you‚Äôre one of those who goes into a coffee shop to charge up without purchasing anything, don‚Äôt.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Agreed. There's always some people or "haters" who get offended on behalf of the person concerned, even with reasonable constructive-criticism, verbally attacking the person. Those other people may be projecting, or it could be any number of reasons. Re the go fund me people, I'm not a big fan of those asking for money, and am skeptical when they say it's in aid of X charity or those who do the "50/50 donation to charity and to the travelling person" thing, I have seen WeLeaf do this a number of times on their social media. I just think "well if they're fundraising, they can do that at home, no travel expenses?" If there was a reliable way to verify where the money goes, that would be great and may easier to be more trusting of fundraisers. One of the few travelling people I've followed who ever seemed genuinely involved in charitable work is: Though it's appreciated if someone is fully transparent on where the money goes instead of them pretending to be charitable when it all goes to the person(s) instead. Maybe I should make a separate post about this in the group...though maybe it's not that relevant for this group.
data.author: Deirdre Clifford

data.author: Pdl Breaking

data.text: First always ask or permission. I stay at campgrounds that have power. I stop for a late breakfast and get permission to charge while I eat. If I stop at a gas station or convenience store for a break I ask permission to plug in. Local churches, libraries, and senior centers are a good place. Sometimes you will find a park with power. One time I plugged into a RVers generator. Don't be afraid to ask strangers.
data.author: Tony Rice

data.text: in the UK and EU all camp sites have electric hook ups, if i stay on a campsite when i go to i make sure i have a 2 plug adapter covers both my batteries or 1 plus my lamp ....
data.author: Raymond Stevens
